title: Interpolation with a function parameter and refined scale of spaces

title_detail.value: Interpolation with a function parameter and refined scale of spaces

summary:
The interpolation of couples of separable Hilbert spaces with a function
parameter is studied. The main properties of the classic interpolation are
proved. Some applications to the interpolation of isotropic H\"ormander spaces
over a closed manifold are given.

summary_detail.value:
The interpolation of couples of separable Hilbert spaces with a function
parameter is studied. The main properties of the classic interpolation are
proved. Some applications to the interpolation of isotropic H\"ormander spaces
over a closed manifold are given.

author: Alexandr A. Murach

Introdu tion

In this paper we study the interpolation of ouples of separable Hilbert spa es with a
fun tional parameter. We generalize the lassi al theorems on interpolation with a power
parameter of order θ ∈ (0, 1) to the maximal lass of fun tions.
As an appli ation, we onsider the interpolation of isotropi Hormander spa es over a losed

kJ1 ukX 0 for any u ∈ X1 . Moreover, these operators are positive. Hen e, they are equal.

a): ψ is Borel measurable on the semiaxis (0, +∞);
b): ψ is bounded on ea h losed interval [a, b], where 0 < a < b < +∞;

Denition 2.2.

A fun tion ψ ∈ B is alled an interpolation parameter if the following
ondition is satised for all admissible ouples X = [X0 , X1 ], Y = [Y0 , Y1 ] of Hilbert spa es
and an arbitrary linear mapping T given on X0 : if the restri tion of the mapping T to the

Otherwise speaking, ψ is an interpolation parameter if and only if the mapping X 7→ Xψ is
an interpolation fun tor given on the ategory of all admissible ouples X of Hilbert spa es
[23, Se . 1.2.2℄, [24, Se . 2.4℄. In the ase where ψ is an interpolation parameter, we say that

A fun tion regularly varying at +∞ with the index θ = 0 is alled a fun tion slowly varying
at +∞.
The theory of regularly varying fun tions was founded by J. Karamata in the 1930s. These
fun tions are losely related to the power fun tions and have numerous appli ations, mainly
due to their spe ial role in Tauberian-type theorems [26, 27, 28, 29℄. A standard example of
fun tions regularly varying at +∞ with the index θ is

ψ(t) = tθ (ln t)r1 (ln ln t)r2 . . . (ln . . . ln t)rk

for t ≫ 1,

where r1 , r2 , . . . , rk ∈ R. In the ase where θ = 0 these fun tions form the logarithmi
multis ale whi h has a number of appli ations in the theory of fun tion spa es.

Denition 3.2.

A positive fun tion ψ dened on a semiaxis [b, +∞) is alled a fun tion
quasiregularly varying at +∞ with the index θ ∈ R if there exist a number b1 ≥ b and
a fun tion ψ1 : [b1 , +∞) → (0, +∞) regularly varying at +∞ with the index θ su h that
ψ(t) ≍ ψ1 (t) with t ≥ b1 . A fun tion quasiregularly varying at +∞ with the index θ = 0 is
alled a fun tion quasislowly varying at +∞.

We denote by QSV the set of all fun tions quasislowly varying at +∞. It is evident that
ψ is a fun tion quasiregularly varying at +∞ with the index θ if and only if ψ(t) = tθ φ(t),
t ≫ 1, for some fun tion φ ∈ QSV. From the known [26, Theorem 1.2℄ integral representation
of a slowly varying fun tion it immediately results the following des ription of the set QSV.
